conclusion: Determine the maximum width of the incident light beam on AB for light to exit the upper surface.
The hemispherical glass has a radius R and light is incident vertically onto AB.
Angle of incidence at the curved surface is determined by refractive properties.
For light to exit, it must undergo total internal reflection; angle of refraction must be less than critical angle.
Critical angle θc is given by sin θc = n_glass / n_air.
Light forms an angle θ relative to the normal at the point of incidence.
In the right triangle, critical angle θc is related to angle θ by sin θc = cos(90° - θ) = sin θ.
Light beam makes an angle of 15° with the vertical when it exits.
Width of the incident beam is determined by angle subtended by θc at edge AB.
Half-width d/2 of the incident beam is R tan(θc / 2).
Full width d of the incident beam is d ≈ 1.57R.
The maximum width of the incident light beam on AB is approximately 1.57R.
